"step_by_step_thinking": "The provided documents suggest that fat consumption is inversely related to blood lipids. In the [Fat consumption, blood lipids and age] document, it is mentioned that obese subjects had lower consumption of total fat in food compared to normal-weight subjects. Similarly, in the [Weight and metabolic changes induced by low carbohydrate-high fat diets in man and in rat] study, an increase in serum cholesterol level was observed when a high-fat diet was consumed.

In the given scenario, where the person is on a fat-free, carbohydrate-rich diet, it can be inferred that their total fat consumption is zero or very low. This could lead to an increase in blood lipids, particularly those related to carbohydrates.

The [Effect of a reduced diet on hyperlipoproteinemia in metabolic-alimentary obesity] document mentions that most patients examined demonstrated hyperlipoproteinemia, basically of the IIb type. The study suggests that following a course of the reduced diet, the frequency of hyperlipoproteinemia of the II, III and IV types declines.

In this context, it is likely that VLDL (very low-density lipoprotein) will be elevated in his blood, as it is related to carbohydrate metabolism and is often increased in cases of obesity.",
"answer_choice": B
